awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF: Collaborative Research: Pre-Skilling Workers, Understanding Labor Force Implications and Designing Future Factory Human-Robot Workflows Using a Physical Simulation Platform
awd_abstract_narration:
The Future of Work at the Human-Technology Frontier (FW-HTF) is one of 10 new Big Ideas for Future Investment announced by NSF. The FW-HTF cross-directorate program aims to respond to the challenges and opportunities of the changing landscape of jobs and work by supporting convergent research. This award fulfills part of that aim.

This collaborative project between Purdue University, Indiana University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is based on the rationale that today's manufacturers, especially small and medium enterprises may struggle to keep pace with rapid changes in manufacturing. To help manufacturers thrive in a rapidly changing industry, this project aims to develop a Physical-Simulation Platform that will realistically simulate interactions between workers, robots, and machines in future factories, and at the same time, improve factory agility and productivity. This project will provide new insights into workers' spatial, multitasking, and predictive task abilities in manufacturing, and their performance in shared and smooth workflows. Those insights can then be used to shape the augmented manufacturing environment of the future by amplifying cognitive capacity and transferring some cognitive burden to artificial intelligence and smart automation.  Such changes can improve both productivity and worker experience. The project will explore the economic impact on different types of workers as well as the benefits of artificial intelligence-based augmentation technologies on human labor, factory productivity and agility. In addition, the project will contribute to workforce development by creating educational plans and outreach to prepare workers for the manufacturing workplace of the future. The researchers will directly engage underserved young people by introducing them to new toolkits and curriculum developed as part of this project.  These materials can then be adapted by educators across the country. Strong industry collaborations are present to facilitate testing and adoption of this approach. 

The research team of mechanical and electrical engineers, psychologists, computer scientists, education researchers, and economists will work toward accomplishing five goals: (1) use Mixed Reality to capture interactions, shared workflows, and collaborative tasks as close as possible to a real manufacturing environment; (2) develop and demonstrate new types of authoring platform to program robots, internet-of-things-based machines, and humans interacting with them, with augmented reality, artificial intelligence to substantially reduce cognitive loads and enhance worker and factory overall capabilities and productivities; (3) discover, design and develop flexible representations of collaborative intelligence workflows and metrics to simulate and evaluate Humans-Robots-Machines shared work; (4) evaluate shared work economics and labor market implications of augmenting humans with robotics, augmented reality, and artificial intelligence; and (5) pre-skill the workforce and increase engagement towards the future of work at the human-technology interface.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project at Purdue University involved a collaborative effort that merged advanced technology, such as augmented reality (AR) and artificial intelligence (AI), with manufacturing and education sectors. Working closely with learning scientists at UC Irvine and economists at MIT, this convergent approach led to significant knowledge creation with direct impacts on both industrial and educational workforce training. This collaborative work was pivotal in making high-level technology accessible and functional in real-world settings.


Major Activities and Achievements
1. Interactive Learning and Authoring Tools:

  • The team developed AR and visual programming tools to enhance human-robot interactions and simplify programming tasks in manufacturing. These tools reduce the difficulty and cost associated with creating extended reality content, lowering barriers to entry and removing the need for specialized expertise.   
  • A system combining crafts, storytelling, and basic programming was also created to help young people develop creative and technical skills through engaging activities.

2. Educational Impact and Workforce Development:

  • The project conducted workshops and developed new educational materials to enhance STEM education, utilizing AR and the Internet of Things (IoT) to create hands-on, immersive learning experiences.   -
  • It also provided direct research and technology engagement opportunities for Ph.D. and Master's students, integrating them into cutting-edge technological developments.

3. Collaborative Research and Industry Engagement:   

In partnership with academic institutions like MIT and UCI, and companies such as Subaru Isuzu and Delta Welding, the team applied their research in practical applications, ensuring the developed technologies are both innovative and applicable in real industrial settings.


4. Technological Innovations and Patents: 

The project led to the development of new technologies and multiple patent filings, including AR tools for machine task training and cloud-based AR systems for collaborative learning. These innovations represent significant advancements in the way humans interact with machines.


5. Dissemination of Research:

- Research findings were extensively shared through conferences, journal articles, and industry discussions, reaching a wide audience. The project's developments were also featured in various media and academic publications, broadening public engagement with the new technologies.


Future Directions
- Enhancing Remote Learning and Training in Hands-on Technologies: 

- The project aims to develop cloud-based platforms that support AR and VR applications for education and training. This advancement is particularly crucial given the increased need for remote learning solutions highlighted by the pandemic.
- Expansion of Collaborative and Context-Aware Systems: 

- Future plans include the development of systems that are more responsive to their environments and users, enhancing the utility of robots and AI in complex scenarios.


The integration of new generative AI technologies, with a focus on human-centered design, is essential for moving forward. Utilizing generative AI will enable the creation of more dynamic and realistic educational content and manufacturing simulations. This approach ensures that technological advancements are practical and beneficial, enhancing the acceptance and effectiveness of mixed reality in manufacturing.


Overall, this project represents a profound effort to integrate cutting-edge technology with practical applications, significantly enhancing educational experiences and manufacturing efficiency in a human-centered manner.
